paragraphs.text: On the surface, the Impossible Burger’s goal to reduce meat consumption sounds important. There are urgent problems with animal factory farming. But at a time when consumers are pushing for more sustainably produced real food, are these biotech products the right answer?
paragraphs.name: cf81

paragraphs.text: Investors and companies are excited to use new genetic engineering techniques, but are doing everything they can to pull the wool over consumers’ eyes. Some of their new products are even being mislabeled as non-GMO or natural, despite being derived from genetically engineered organisms and grown in a lab.
paragraphs.name: 86a9

paragraphs.text: Do we really want to produce our food with patented, gene-edited fungi or algae, fed with chemical-intensive, environmentally destructive feedstocks such as GMO corn or sugarcane, and made in labs? Or do we want to move towards a food system based on transparency and truly regenerative, organic agriculture that is sustainable and healthy for farmers, farmworkers, our planet, and consumers?
paragraphs.name: b61e

paragraphs.text: But where’s the data? What is the environmental footprint of the feedstock required to feed the GE algae? What is the overall lifecycle impact of this product? How are the GE ingredients contained? These are some questions that must be answered transparently before these products can reasonably claim the halo of sustainability.
paragraphs.name: 65b4

paragraphs.text: Do we really want to produce our food with patented, gene-edited fungi or algae, fed with chemical-intensive, environmentally destructive feedstocks such as GMO corn or sugarcane, and made in labs? Or do we want to move towards a food system based on transparency and truly regenerative, organic agriculture that is sustainable and healthy for farmers, farmworkers, our planet, and consumers?
paragraphs.name: b61e

paragraphs.text: While we and many in the environmental and animal welfare community are fully in support of reducing unsustainable meat consumption, in an era where consumers are increasingly demanding transparency and “real” food and running full speed away from processed, industrial food, it would seem that non-GMO, organic, plant-based meat alternatives that carry less inherent risks are a wiser direction.
paragraphs.name: 7b81

paragraphs.text: Companies introducing these new GMOs to the market are essentially self-regulated and are asking consumers to blindly trust them.
paragraphs.name: a9d9

15d3e3a04e69.title: Sure, some people are going organic, but are most people?

paragraphs.text: Sure, some people are going organic, but are most people?
paragraphs.name: 610e

paragraphs.text: Such as? Using the term “factory farming” is provocative, but is rarely accompanied by data to support claims of a lack of sustainability, humane treatment, and transparency.
paragraphs.name: 16d0

paragraphs.text: Great read! I fear that GMO’s are here to stay and it worries me mostly because I just don’t think the science boys really know the unintended consequences of their work. We have problems occurring without explanations, everything from bees to autism, ocean dead zones and superweeds. We have corporate monoculture farming where soils are sterilized…
paragraphs.name: c62d

846a2719c41e.title: Science is about inquiry and the search for truth.

paragraphs.text: Science is about inquiry and the search for truth. Questions about safety and environmental impact are only irrelevant to companies that have something to hide.
paragraphs.name: 0fd6

6aed1fe2834.title: What would that look like, exactly?

paragraphs.text: What would that look like, exactly?
paragraphs.name: 5a94

paragraphs.text: I see a lot of trigger words in this article like GMO, “chemically-intensive,” and “environmentally destructive feedstocks,” but not a lot of data, logic or proof.
The most intractable problem you’ve hinted at seems to be excessive use of a single herbicide. If we can solve that problem… ?

virtuals.subtitle: I see a lot of trigger words in this article like GMO, “chemically-intensive,” and “environmentally destructive feedstocks,” but not a lot…

content.subtitle: I see a lot of trigger words in this article like GMO, “chemically-intensive,” and “environmentally destructive feedstocks,” but not a lot…

paragraphs.text: Indeed, where is the data? You have produced very little in support of your arguments. Furthermore, you seem to be demanding for more transparency from producers you deem to be using GMOs than from other producers. Would you be asking all of these questions of a food producer that slapped “organic” on all of their products? I’m not suggesting…
paragraphs.name: c558

ab9af34676e5.title: You have raised some fair questions, transparency throughout the food production process is of…

paragraphs.text: You have raised some fair questions, transparency throughout the food production process is of extreme importance, not to mention for everything else really.
paragraphs.name: 9c9e

paragraphs.text: However, I couldn’t help but notice the tendency to flag Genetic modification / engineering as bad by default.
paragraphs.name: 6b39

virtuals.subtitle: However, I couldn’t help but notice the tendency to flag Genetic modification / engineering as bad by default.

content.subtitle: However, I couldn’t help but notice the tendency to flag Genetic modification / engineering as bad by default.

paragraphs.text: Can you provide an example? It’s probably worth pointing out that “natural” is an incredibly subjective term — food production in general is unnatural, even if somebody calls it organic.
paragraphs.name: 8f28
